repnme.cdata!:
Niger - First Education, Primary Education
            Development, and Basic Education Sector Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The audit concurs, by and large, with
            ratings by the Implementation Completion reports as follows:
            on the First Education, and the Primary Education
            Development Projects, ratings convey satisfactory project
            outcomes, likely sustainability, with only modest
            institutional development impacts; yet, on assessing the
            Basic Education Sector Project, the audit downgrades project
            outcome to moderately unsatisfactory, concurs on modest
            institutional development impacts, but considers
            sustainability non-evaluable, and, both Bank and Borrower
            performances are downgraded to unsatisfactory. Experience
            with the assessed projects confirms a number of lessons: 1)
            A policy framework focused on costs and access is
            insufficient. The two primary education projects emphasized
            cost savings over instruction on basic skills. Policy
            dialogue and project activities need to focus on student
            acquisition of basic skills. Providing mass education under
            clearly inadequate instructional conditions may graduate
            functional illiterates, and benefit only those who are the
            brightest, or better-off. 2) Access-related indicators may
            be relatively easy to obtain, but may not be closely related
            to learning achievements. Monitoring indicators for the two
            primary education projects showcased enrollment increases
            and improvements in student flows, but not whether students
            had acquired basic knowledge and skills. Innovative and
            rapid means must be sought to gauge students'
            achievements (such as the proportion of students able to
            read fluently a simple text.). Procurement planning must aim
            at making large numbers of textbooks available to students
            for free, but also available for sale at the market.
            Textbook management is most effective if it takes into
            account the printing strengths of the local private sector,
            and the community school associations. Though in other
            countries enrollments in agricultural schools tend to be low
            and labor linkages weak, in Niger there is a demand for the
            skills provided. Bank investments of earlier decades in
            agricultural education may continue to provide skills
            relevant to the economy, if policy dialogue is focused
            toward modernizing courses, generating income to schools,
            and catering to the populations likely to be interested in
            agricultural training.

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Basic Education
            Project (Hybrid) is rated as satisfactory, sustainability as
            likely, institutional development impact as modest, Bank
            performance as satisfactory, and borrower performance as
            satisfactory. The key lessons learned include: The hybrid
            financial instrument increased effectiveness in the
            implementation of sectoral reforms. Cost-sharing in school
            construction raised implementation and equity issues. Good
            leadership and sustained commitment to the implementation of
            measures ensuring improved quality of education are key. The
            implementation of teacher recruitment reforms requires time,
            patience, and an adequate risk management strategy.
            Efficient textbook distribution is key to ensuring
            availability of books in the classroom. Thorough explanation
            regarding project activities are of paramount practice.
            Communications between the coordinating unit and component
            directors must be comfortable and frequent. Financial
            management reviewers recommend that a) personnel performance
            and evaluation procedures should be rigorously followed; and
            b) the financial management coordination unit produce and
            publish a quarterly activity report to all involved partners.

abstracts.cdata!:
Niger is one of the five countries in
            the world that have less than one-third of their children
            enrolled in primary education.  Although primary school
            enrollment increased by 73% between 1980 and 1993, due to
            high population growth, the enrollment coverage in 1993 was
            only marginally higher than in 1980.  The Government has
            developed an Emergency Education Rehabilitation Plan (EERP),
            designed to initiate a transformation of Niger's
            education system from a small, elitist and costly system
            into one that is more relevant and equitable.  The project
            will support implementation of EERP between 1994 and 1999
            with the objective of increasing the primary school
            enrollment ratio from 29% to 35%.  The project will achieve
            this objective by implementing a sector reform program
            designed to: 1) increase public expenditures on primary
            education; 2) extend the use of double-shift teaching in
            primary education; 3) restructure and consolidate training
            of primary school teachers; 4) consolidate training of
            secondary school teachers; 5) use teachers more efficiently;
            and 5) contain student subsidies in secondary and higher
            education.  The project will also improve access to quality
            of primary education by constructing classrooms; providing
            school textbooks; developing and implementing a program to
            accelerate girl's education; and improving teacher
            training programs. Finally, the project will strengthen
            sector managerial and planning capacities by: strengthening
            the capacity of the Ministry of Education to manage
            education resources and implement and evaluate education
            improvement programs; improving the efficiency of
            decentralized sector planning and management; and preparing
            a development strategy for higher education.
